VERY_SHORT.string: Neil deGrasse Tyson Answers Cosmic Queries on Star Talk

SHORT.string: Neil deGrasse Tyson and Chuck Nice answer a variety of fan questions on Star Talk. Topics include the possibility of observing 2D and 4D beings, the practicality of space elevators, and whether light can perform work, as demonstrated by solar sails. They also discuss if AI can replace human teachers, the nature of spacetime and gravity, and the feasibility of time travel, considering the universe's expansion. The conversation covers galaxy collisions, supermassive black holes, and a speculative idea that spacetime might be a crystalline lattice.

MEDIUM.markdown_string:
# Neil deGrasse Tyson Answers Cosmic Queries on Star Talk

In this wide-ranging episode of *Star Talk Cosmic Queries*, host Neil deGrasse Tyson and co-host Chuck Nice dive into a fascinating grab bag of questions from listeners around the world. From the nature of dimensions and the feasibility of space elevators to the mysteries of time travel and the role of black holes in galactic evolution, no cosmic stone is left unturned.

---

## Could We Ever Detect 2D Beings—and What Would 4D Beings See in Us?

A listener from Bucharest, Romania, named Alex posed a mind-bending question about dimensions:

> “I often hear that dark matter or dark energy could be the 4D leaking into our 3D space, but living in 3D space, can we ever actually observe a truly 2D space? And if not, wouldn't that mean 4D beings couldn't interfere with our world either, just as we don't notice any real 2D beings?”

Tyson acknowledged the logic: if 2D beings existed, how would we even detect them? He recalled an old internet cartoon where a 2D character turned sideways and disappeared—because with zero thickness, they’d be invisible from the edge.

> “A 2D world in front of us would be completely visible. You would see light reflecting off their substance… Only when they go sideways do they disappear from your view.”

Extending the analogy to 4D beings observing us, Tyson noted that just as we could see inside a 2D being’s “organs” (since they’re enclosed only by a line), a 4D being would see directly into our bodies.

> “They’ll see all your guts… The first thing we’d do when we have four-dimensional beings is make them medical doctors. It’s a game of Operation for them—nothing to it.”

---

## Is a “Starbridge” or Space Elevator Actually Possible?

Jeff from Tennessee asked about the space elevator depicted in Apple TV’s adaptation of Isaac Asimov’s *Foundation*—specifically, the “Starbridge” on the planet Trantor.

Tyson confirmed that, in theory, a space elevator is conceivable. The idea is to reach orbit without rockets, simply by riding an elevator to geosynchronous orbit—about 23,000 miles up.

But there’s a catch:

> “If your elevator were going 1,000 miles an hour, it would take 23 hours. We already get to space quicker than that.”

He pointed out that with advances in commercial spaceflight—especially from companies like SpaceX—the practical urgency for space elevators has faded. Plus, the engineering challenges remain immense.

> “Space elevator is a cool technological achievement, but I don't see it happening. It was a solution to a non-problem.”

---

## If an Alien Gave You One Answer, What Would You Ask?

A listener named Raphael from Toronto posed a tantalizing hypothetical:

> “If a super intelligent extraterrestrial offered to grant you the answer to one specific question, what would you ask?”

Tyson didn’t hesitate:

> “Is the human brain sufficiently smart to figure out the entire universe? That's a question I want to answer because if it's not, then I'll buffer my expectations. But if it is, then onward we would march.”

He elaborated that some cosmic mysteries—like quantum mechanics—might only seem mysterious because of our cognitive limitations.

Chuck, on the other hand, had a more… practical query:

> “I would like to know: are there cheaper eggs somewhere in the universe than where I buy mine right now? Because they are hugely expensive.”

Tyson laughed but offered his own profound question:

> “What happened before the Big Bang? I don’t mean what happened—I mean, what was there before? Give me the lay of the land before the Big Bang.”

---

## Do Aliens Poop? And Other Digestive Mysteries

Marcus from Germany wondered about the infamous xenomorph from *Alien*:

> “Did you ever think about the alien in *Alien* not needing any digestive organs since its blood is acid? So all human flesh it eats is directly dissolved into molecules. So the alien doesn't need to produce poop since it can use 100% of its food. Or did you ever see the alien take a poop?”

Tyson took the question in stride:

> “A poopless alien is totally fine. There's nothing wrong with a poopless alien.”

He contrasted this with Superman—another alien—who would have a “super digestive tract,” and hypothetical plant-based aliens whose waste product might be oxygen.

> “But then they have to rewrite that kids' book: *Everybody Poops*.”

---

## Can AI Truly Replace Human Teachers?

Matthew, a globe-trekking teacher, asked whether an AI that perfectly replicates a teacher’s knowledge, style, and personality could ever replace the human connection essential for learning.

Tyson was skeptical:

> “If you are teaching today, with methods, tools, and tactics, and then I clone that… I'm not given any reason to think that your clone would not be as effective as you are in those situations.”

But, he added, great teachers do more than deliver content—they adapt on the fly:

> “AI can ape your style… but it can't intuit something different that might be happening in a student and then make an adjustment… That frontier, at least for my foreseeable future, remains in the realm of the inventive, creative teacher.”

---

## Is Spacetime Naturally Flat?

DJ from Maine asked whether spacetime has a “natural” flat state, and if something like “gravitational entropy” restores flatness once mass or energy is removed.

Tyson clarified:

> “If you remove the matter and energy, there's no reason for spacetime to be curved at all. I'm given no reason to think that space would have any shape other than flat after you remove the items that would curve it.”

He also noted that the large-scale shape of the universe—open, closed, or flat—is a separate issue, related to cosmic expansion rather than local gravity.

---

## If a Star Is Dead, Is It Still “There”?

Keith from Northern California wondered whether we can think of a “universal now,” and whether stars we see in the night sky—whose light may be billions of years old—still exist in our present.

Tyson reframed the question:

> “We see things not as they are, but as they once were… We're interacting with light that is currently reaching us. And when that light was emitted, [the star] was alive.”

He added a fun thought experiment:

> “Find a galaxy 33 million light-years away. If they all held up mirrors and you looked at those mirrors, you would see the dinosaurs going extinct.”

---

## Time Travel: Do You Need the Universe’s Center?

Anthony from Seattle—and his 11-year-old son—asked a detailed time-travel question: to travel accurately through time, would you need to account for the expansion of the universe and locate its center?

Tyson admitted the math was beyond him but cited physicist Richard Gott’s work:

> “Rich Gott would say you can… using mathematical trajectories in the vicinity of black holes. In principle, yes.”

He also touched on the “bootstrap paradox,” referencing *Back to the Future* and the idea of a “Jinn song”—a piece of music that has no origin, existing only in a time loop.

---

## Does Light Do Any Work?

Todd, a retired naval officer and Earth science teacher, couldn’t resist:

> “Does light ever do any work? It does light work.”

Tyson answered with a real-world example: solar sails.

> “The Planetary Society… built and launched a solar sail… They opened it up, angled it, and saw if sunlight could press on that solar sail and increase its orbit around the Earth. And it did. So light is doing work.”

He also described the Breakthrough Starshot initiative, which aims to use powerful ground-based lasers to propel tiny, stamp-sized “nanoprobes” to Alpha Centauri at 20% the speed of light.

> “If it reaches 20% the speed of light and Alpha Centauri is four light-years away… it would take 20 years to get there. But then to send a signal back? That’s another four years. So you’d know what it found after 24 years.”

---

## Do Galaxies Get Swallowed by Their Black Holes?

Jean-François from Quebec asked whether supermassive black holes eventually consume their entire host galaxies.

Tyson’s answer was a firm *no*:

> “A black hole is really tiny relative to the galaxy… The mass of the galaxy swamps the mass of the black hole.”

He explained that only matter very close to the black hole gets drawn in—most stars orbit peacefully, unaffected.

> “If you turn our Sun into a black hole—it wouldn’t happen naturally, but if you magic-hands it—we’d still orbit it. We’d just freeze to death.”

When galaxies collide, however, their central black holes can spiral toward each other and merge—a spectacular cosmic event.

---

## Is Spacetime a Crystal Lattice?

Patrick, a self-described “science nerd from Texas,” proposed a radical idea:

> “What if spacetime itself is a super-solid lattice where defects create natural time loops that erase paradoxes? And the so-called mystery echoes LIGO is hearing are actually the fingerprints of that lattice?”

Tyson was intrigued:

> “If it's a lattice, then you can think about crystal lattices… We would have to propose experiments to check whether phenomena that unfolds within the lattice is different when viewed at different angles.”

He praised the creativity behind the question, even if it remains speculative:

> “I like it. It's very creative. Maybe you can develop it further.”

---

## Closing

As always, Tyson signed off with gratitude for the listeners and their endlessly curious questions:

> “You people, you're amazing… Keep looking up.”

Another installment of *Star Talk Cosmic Queries* proves that the universe is just as full of wonder as the minds exploring it.
